@stepanblyschak 

I don't have object to the claim that we might only have needs to use warm/fast reboot features on T0 switches.

However, these features are generic enough that they could also be used on T1 switches. We could discuss if we want to test this feature on T1 switches. Personally I think we should. Because there is no mechanism to prevent switch admin from invoke warm/fast reboot on T1 switch, then we should test it.

This discussion doesn't have to block this PR. IMO.

Let's reuse code in existing fib.yml instead of copying and modifying. This is a previous sample https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/pull/733

My quick suggestion:
1. keep shared code in fib.yml
2. wrap old fib test in a new file fib-cold.yml
3. add a new test case in a new file fib-warm.yml

 #Closed

[fib_shred.yml]: moved shared code in this file.

[fib.yml]: remove shared part and added include fib_shared.yml. I prefer same name i.e. fib.yml for test cases because it may be used in many other places.

[fib_warm_restart.yml]
Async playbook in Sonic test-frame-work are written with assumption that most of the task will run on DUT until we delegate it to another Machine.
So this playbook uses async-poll ansible module to run ptf tasks in parallel with docker/system restart.

Notice: In Result, Next task starts within 1 secs after PTF, because PTF part runs in parallel.

> I prefer same name i.e. fib.yml for test cases because it may be used in many other places.

Changing filename to 'simple-fib.yml' is safe as long as we keep command line or test case name unchanged.

Suggest filenames:
- fib_warm_restart.yml -> warm-reboot-fib.yml
- fib_shared.yml -> shared-fib.yml

Suggest test case names:
- fib_warm_restart -> warm-reboot-fib #Closed

In reply to: [436689067](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/pull/733#issuecomment-436689067) [](ancestors = 436689067)

Hi Roman,

What ansible version do you use? I never had an issue with the current sources.
Also as I see from the docs
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.5/modules/copy_module.html

dest  | Remote absolute path where the file should be copied to. If src is a directory, this must be a directory too. **If dest is a nonexistent path and if either dest ends with "/"** or src is a directory, dest is created. If src and dest are files, the parent directory of dest isn't created: the task fails if it doesn't already exist.

So it looks like your DUT device doesn't have /root directory and by adding "/" to the end of the directory name you force ansible to create it. In this case, it's better to change the logic.
I think it's better to use $HOME, or /tmp, but don't create some cruft in the system.

Hi Pavel,

Our Ansible is 2.0.0.2.

The issues is reproduced 
when dest /root folder already contains a file to be copied
and 'dest' is a sym link to the folder:
/root -> /var/home/root

In this case Ansible copy fails with
"msg": "src file does not exist"
although source and destination exist.

I tried copy with force=yes, and mode=0777
none of them resolved the failure.

One solution is to add a step before the copying
to check if the destination folder already has the file to be copied, and then apply 'when' to copy.

Another solution is to specify 'dest' explicitly (complying with the Ansible documentation):
dest: /root/fanout_listener.py

The solution with the least changes implies specifying 'dest' as a directory - with trailing '/'.

Hi Roman,

Thank you for the details

comments.body: @maggiesMSFT as this was already approved 21 days, please merge.
typo: through instead of throw

Could you elaborate the reason? Is it a platform specific issue?
> Currently there are 4 pings sent but sometimes it is not enough because it takes some time to bring up IP interface and add neighbor.

It doesn't look like platform specific issue, I observed it on different platforms.
Currently test configures IPs for 2 interfaces on PTF host and then immediately runs ```ping -c 4``` in background. Ping is needed in order to force SONiC DUT to add neighbors for 2 newly configured PTF host interfaces. Sometimes these neighbors are not added on DUT and as a result test fails with the error that packets are received on unexpected port (they go via default route, since neighbors are not installed). So, sometimes 4 ping packets are not enough, it could happen because, e.g. IP configuration could be not applied yet when ping is sent.

Implemented solution is to allow to send up to 10 ping packets, but once neighbor is reachable stop sending. (With these changes issue is not observed anymore)
Unfortunately I'm not familiar with both the test and its setup. Sihui initially made the test. So I added her as a reviewer here.
Thanks @volodymyrsamotiy! How do you know 10 ping packets are just enough while 4 are not?

I just took 10 as big enough number (to make sure that it will always pass) and added logic to stop ping once neighbor is reachable in order to send only required number of packets but not 10 all the time.

comments.body: technically it is not a bug, it was working by design.
This replaced #491

Regarding "it appears that the pysnmp takes one timeout and applies to all subsequent queries", I don't believe it is the root cause. To troubleshoot, I suggested more experiment:
1. Run playbook and leaving temporary script on ansible host
```
ANSIBLE_KEEP_REMOTE_FILES=1 ansible-playbook ...
```
2. Run the temporary script for snmp_facts to make sure the bug is inside this plugin
3. Debug this python script to make sure the UdpTransportTarget() timeout

Qi,

You are absolute right about the timeout only used by one command. With pdb, I was able to see that 1.0 second was used by subsequent queries.

I think what happened is that one of the subsequent query is also marginal at 1 second, yesterday during my tests, it happened several times that if I remove some query from the first group without changing the timeout, another group would fail. With increased timeout on the first group. I never ran into trouble.

So anyways, I increase timeout to 10 seconds for all queries. Please take another look.

Thanks,
Ying

Joe,

Thanks for the good catch! Changed now.

Regards,
Ying

Thanks Qi,

I changed the comment accordingly.

Regards,
Ying

comments.body: ansible/roles/sonic-common/tasks/snmp.yml

The default remote.py in ptf package only support 32-port platform. For 64 port platform, we need to use the remote.py deployed in ptftests dir. therefore, we added --platform-dir in the ptf command line, and the new remote.py is backward compatible with the default ptf remote.py
